author: Wilhelm Arcturus

text: Here it is, the day after New Year’s, the first real work day of the year for many as we face a cold winter and an uncertain future… and Steam will have shut down the Winter Sale by the time you read this.  How can we possibly carry on? Steam Winter Sale 2024 Well, we all know that another sale is around the corner.  Steam has trained us to expect that, if nothing else.   While we’re all waiting for that, it is now time to go over the Steam end of year stuff. First off, what did I buy this year?  At the last minute I pulled the trigger on two items in my cart. The big Winter Sale buying spree Astroneer and Empyrion – Galactic Survival are both sci-fi co-op survival builders that had been hanging around on my wishlist since last year.  Potshot already owns one of them, so maybe we’ll get around to them at some point. Also a special TAGN thank you goes out to Mrrx of To Game For Life blog bought me a copy of The Escapist 2, which was on my wishlist.  So I did end up with three new titles.  Now to find the time for them. The Steam Winter Sale is also the framework for the Steam Awards.  As I predicted back at the start of the sale, Black Myth Wukong won Game of the Year, along with two other categories. Steam 2024 Game of the Year Not a game I played nor one I am interested in and the win is only notable to me because of its predictability due to nationalist fervor.  I was only interested in Balatro, which I was surprised even made the nomination for Game of the Year. As it was Balatro didn’t make the cut for any awards, even the most innovative game play, which went to Liar’s Bar. Steam 2024 Most Innovative Game Play Part of me wonders how a title based on Liar’s Dice could get there… but then Balatro is pretty much based on Poker, so you can innovate from a basic formula… and I haven’t played Liar’s Bar, so couldn’t speak to how much innovation there really was.  Also, this is a user poll on the topic, and we’re notoriously bad at picking based off any criteria outside of familiarity. That also explains Elden Ring winning the Labor of Love award even though No Man’s Sky or Stardew Valley were, in my opinion, the only options that really met the criteria.  The NMS subreddit was pissed. Not that winning or losing means anything in the end to me, though it probably means some sales to the winners and something else to put on the marketing materials. The 2024 Steam Awards Winners There was also the Best of Steam 2024 announcements, of which Top Sellers and Most Played are probably the most interesting of the metrics to me. Top Sellers is the top 100 titles based on gross revenue for 2024, and can be read as something of a financial health meter in that, if your game made the cut, it is probably in pretty good shape given there are somewhere north of 100K titles on Steam now.  These are the 0.1% elite titles for revenue and I recognize and even own some of them. The Gold Tier – 13 through 24 – Gross Sales Glad to see Enshrouded in the gold tier, which is enough to give one hope that my wish from yesterday may be granted.  Likewise, Path of Exile 2 seems to be shaping up. For Most Played it is broken out by peak concurrent players, with the cut offs at 450K, 200K, 100K, and 50K.  Path of Exile 2 made it into the Platinum rank for that, a good sign for its future I am sure. I am less interested in VR, Steam Deck, or Controller titles, though the gross revenue ranking for New Releases has some level of influence… Path of Exile 2 made it into the Platinum rank for that… not bad considering it hit paid early access in December.  Enshrouded made it into the Gold ranking for that as well. And then there was the annual Steam Hardware Survey, linked at the bottom with the other key items.  That is always a bit of an insight.  Windows remains the operating system of choice for 98% of respondents.  Just reality-ville there. The average free hard drive space makes me itch… but I am a bit obsessive about that sort of thing. But the main thing I look at is monitor resolutions, and what is popular.  The ranking this year: Rank Resolution % of Resp 1 1920 x 1080 55.98% 2 2560 x 1440 19.75% 3 2560 x 1600 4.62% 4 3840 x 2160 4.21% 5 1366 x 768 2.90% 6 Other 2.79% 7 3440 x 1440 2.51% 8 1920 x 1200 1.45% 9 1440 x 900 0.90% 10 1600 x 900 0.90% 11 2560 x 1080 0.86% 12 1680 x 1050 0.56% 13 1360 x 768 0.55% 14 800 x 1280 0.48% 15 2880 x 1800 0.37% 16 1280 x 800 0.35% 17 5120 x 1440 0.32% 18 1280 x 1024 0.29% 19 1280 x 720 0.21% 1920×1080 remains the default size for a majority of respondents.  Another reason for certain game companies to not worry about any larger resolution.  But it continues to slowly trend down.  It had been 60% last year, and 65% the year before that. So it goes.  Another Steam Winter Sales fades into the past as we set out into the reality of a new year.  Aside from buying two titles and getting one as a gift, my other big sale discovery was that you can spend your Steam points to increase the size of entries on your profile, so now if you stumble upon my profile it now has two more rows of achievements in my showcase. My rarest achievements I have a number from Lost Ark that were not that hard to get, but I guess people never really tried.  Most of the rest are from Civ V where I won with some of the less popular factions I guess and Age of Empires II where… I guess the same? Now we’re on to 2025. The Best of Steam 2024 The 2024 Steam Awards Winners The Steam Hardware Survey 2024 My Steam Replay 2024
html:
Here it is, the day after New Year’s, the first real work day of the year for many as we face a cold winter and an uncertain future… and Steam will have shut down the Winter Sale by the time you read this.  How can we possibly carry on?

Steam Winter Sale 2024

Well, we all know that another sale is around the corner.  Steam has trained us to expect that, if nothing else.   While we’re all waiting for that, it is now time to go over the Steam end of year stuff.

First off, what did I buy this year?  At the last minute I pulled the trigger on two items in my cart.

The big Winter Sale buying spree

Astroneer and Empyrion – Galactic Survival are both sci-fi co-op survival builders that had been hanging around on my wishlist since last year.  Potshot already owns one of them, so maybe we’ll get around to them at some point.

Also a special TAGN thank you goes out to Mrrx of To Game For Life blog bought me a copy of The Escapist 2, which was on my wishlist.  So I did end up with three new titles.  Now to find the time for them.

The Steam Winter Sale is also the framework for the Steam Awards.  As I predicted back at the start of the sale, Black Myth Wukong won Game of the Year, along with two other categories.

Steam 2024 Game of the Year

Not a game I played nor one I am interested in and the win is only notable to me because of its predictability due to nationalist fervor.  I was only interested in Balatro, which I was surprised even made the nomination for Game of the Year.

As it was Balatro didn’t make the cut for any awards, even the most innovative game play, which went to Liar’s Bar.

Steam 2024 Most Innovative Game Play

Part of me wonders how a title based on Liar’s Dice could get there… but then Balatro is pretty much based on Poker, so you can innovate from a basic formula… and I haven’t played Liar’s Bar, so couldn’t speak to how much innovation there really was.  Also, this is a user poll on the topic, and we’re notoriously bad at picking based off any criteria outside of familiarity.

That also explains Elden Ring winning the Labor of Love award even though No Man’s Sky or Stardew Valley were, in my opinion, the only options that really met the criteria.  The NMS subreddit was pissed.

Not that winning or losing means anything in the end to me, though it probably means some sales to the winners and something else to put on the marketing materials.

The 2024 Steam Awards Winners

There was also the Best of Steam 2024 announcements, of which Top Sellers and Most Played are probably the most interesting of the metrics to me.

Top Sellers is the top 100 titles based on gross revenue for 2024, and can be read as something of a financial health meter in that, if your game made the cut, it is probably in pretty good shape given there are somewhere north of 100K titles on Steam now.  These are the 0.1% elite titles for revenue and I recognize and even own some of them.

The Gold Tier – 13 through 24 – Gross Sales

Glad to see Enshrouded in the gold tier, which is enough to give one hope that my wish from yesterday may be granted.  Likewise, Path of Exile 2 seems to be shaping up.

For Most Played it is broken out by peak concurrent players, with the cut offs at 450K, 200K, 100K, and 50K.  Path of Exile 2 made it into the Platinum rank for that, a good sign for its future I am sure.

I am less interested in VR, Steam Deck, or Controller titles, though the gross revenue ranking for New Releases has some level of influence… Path of Exile 2 made it into the Platinum rank for that… not bad considering it hit paid early access in December.  Enshrouded made it into the Gold ranking for that as well.

And then there was the annual Steam Hardware Survey, linked at the bottom with the other key items.  That is always a bit of an insight.  Windows remains the operating system of choice for 98% of respondents.  Just reality-ville there.

The average free hard drive space makes me itch… but I am a bit obsessive about that sort of thing.

But the main thing I look at is monitor resolutions, and what is popular.  The ranking this year:

Rank Resolution % of Resp
1 1920 x 1080 55.98%
2 2560 x 1440 19.75%
3 2560 x 1600 4.62%
4 3840 x 2160 4.21%
5 1366 x 768 2.90%
6 Other 2.79%
7 3440 x 1440 2.51%
8 1920 x 1200 1.45%
9 1440 x 900 0.90%
10 1600 x 900 0.90%
11 2560 x 1080 0.86%
12 1680 x 1050 0.56%
13 1360 x 768 0.55%
14 800 x 1280 0.48%
15 2880 x 1800 0.37%
16 1280 x 800 0.35%
17 5120 x 1440 0.32%
18 1280 x 1024 0.29%
19 1280 x 720 0.21%

1920×1080 remains the default size for a majority of respondents.  Another reason for certain game companies to not worry about any larger resolution.  But it continues to slowly trend down.  It had been 60% last year, and 65% the year before that.

So it goes.  Another Steam Winter Sales fades into the past as we set out into the reality of a new year.  Aside from buying two titles and getting one as a gift, my other big sale discovery was that you can spend your Steam points to increase the size of entries on your profile, so now if you stumble upon my profile it now has two more rows of achievements in my showcase.

My rarest achievements

I have a number from Lost Ark that were not that hard to get, but I guess people never really tried.  Most of the rest are from Civ V where I won with some of the less popular factions I guess and Age of Empires II where… I guess the same?

Now we’re on to 2025.
